bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 15, 1879

div1.p: Reed arrives at Fort Apache. He describes his house, and relays news of their friends. He studies Spanish.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 15, 1879
div1.p:
I reached here, yesterday afternoon,
after a journey of 18 days from Otero- I found
awaiting me 2 letters from Sister Ellen; one dated
March 5th & the other April 7th. The lament of both
was, “Come home as soon as you can, for we are
so anxious to see you and baby-” She didn't know that
you had started- The day on which her last letter
was written we were journeying to Old Fort
Wingate. There was also a short letter from Pa
dated April 20th- said that he had got my let-
-ter and postal both, & had seen the telegram to John
Vaughan, and that, next morning, all hands, except
himself, would meet you at the boat, & give you
a hearty welcome. I was so much relieved and
delighted to get Pa's letter & to know that some one
would meet you & son at the boat- I know now
that you got back home safely, which lifts a
very great burden from my mind- I thought
that I had missed you before, my little darling,
but I didn't realize how great a void you
had left until my return to Apache- Oh! how
lovely and desolate it seems here without you
my pretty little wife and my sweet “bad daddies”-
I am utterly lost- I intend to go back & live in
the same quarters we occupied- Shall take the par-
lor & hall & have Altman at present, busily at
work cleaning up & scrubbing- Our bed-room stands
just as we left- Poor little Lawrence's cradle al-
most brought the tears- I had to turn away- The
memories were to sweet- I couldn't live in that
room to save me- Dr McPherson, I think, will
take it, & then we will enjoy the spacious hall in
Common- Poor little Undnia, my darling wife, has
remained at the houseful, as a faithful little
guardian ever since my absence- She has only
left for a few minutes at a time to get food
& then would go back & remain in the yard,
day & night- no one would could coax her away-
While I was taking my bath, I sent Altman
for her- He brought her to the door & put her inside
of the room- I didn't look at her or say a word-
At first, she started to another part of the
room, without seeing me- but suddenly turned
& came bounding to me in all ecstacy of delight.
I never saw such demonstrations of happiness.
She whined & jumped about here & there & tore around
the room as if she was crazy- would not let me put
my socks on- was up in my lap & kissing me, & then
down about my feet & tearing around the room
as if she had lost her senses- Has staid right
with me, & last night slept by my bed in the
large house & by 3 o'clock, this morning, was under
the cover & nestling close to my back- This is the
first night she has spent away from the old house
since we left. I tell you, my darling Emilie, this
affection & faithfulness, on little Undie's part,
went straight to my heart, and no money can
buy her- She comes east with me, if it takes twenty
five dollars- She will be lots of company to
me & a constant reminder of my loved ones-
Friday, May 16th- I have again been busy all
day to-day, my darling wife, fixing up my Quar-
ters- The Nuncio & myself have worked hard all day
& have about done everything necessary- except
to get two panes of glass put in the back window
and put up strings for the hop vines- You would
be astonished to see how prettily all the quar-
ters are covered with hop vines- They had no
cold weather during my absence & hence every-
thing is looking very green & beautiful- The flowers
that you gave Col. C. are very pretty & he & Mrs.
C. are very proud of them- Would my precious
little wife like to know what my bed-room looks
like? Well I'll describe it- Firstly, I've got at my
windows the green shades & lace curtains which
we left upnpacked- to-morrow, I am going to get
some pretty pink ribbon from the Suller's to
tie them or rather loop them back with & then, they
will look real pretty & stylish- I haven't got
any pretty little wifie to tie a pretty bow for me
so that I am afraid it will give me much trouble
to get them all straight & nice, but the Nuncio & myself
will do our best- I've got a hospital bed-stead,
two mattrasses & plenty of bed clothing - a nice white
counterpane- The bed stands in the left hand corner
as you enter the room- I have taken our old dining ta-
ble as a centre table & put my table cover on it & also my
pigeon hole desk, containing my papers, stands on the table-
between the back window & the corner book-shelves, stands
the bureau with looking-glass swinging gracefully
above it- Directly opposite the bureau on the other
side of the room, is the wardrobe & on the other side
of the front window stands the washstand- my trunk
is in the corner behind the door- On the floor reposes
pensively the old bear skin & a Luni blanket which
I purchased on my travels- The corner book-shelves
are filled with books & the mantel-piece groans
under a few likewise - on one side of the looking-glass
is suspended the shaving can which my darling wife
made for me- Just below it hangs the wisp broom.
I forgot to say that my mantel is also adorned with
an owl & a duck, one at each end, specimens of
Luni pottery which I will bring east- my pictures
I don't think I will hang up, nor my little precious, for
the very good reason that I haven't got any.
My hall is decorated with my little round, folding table,
on which stands the water pitcher & tumbler; a nice
white mat, which I found in my wash, under each-
A few chairs idle away their time around the table-
On the side-board, are seen some bottles of medicines
which the Nuncio has arranged very artistically.
Undina adorns the front porch, & my house is de-
scribed- Now don't you, my pretty little Emilie,
wifie, wish that you were back, just to live in
such nice, comfortable quarters? I had no idea
that I would make my room look so well- If I
only had a good board floor, instead of the rough
unplaned boards, my room would look real
comfortable- But I am entirely satisfied, for I
know it will only be a few months before I
leave, and about as happy & contented as I can be
without my own precious wife & boy with me- what
did they all say of “bad daddies”,? Tell papa every-
thing they said about his lovely little boy, for papa
knows that none of them had ever seen such a
splendid specimen of a boy before- I want to
know just what sister Ellen thinks of him-
give me her exact words- for I know she thinks
he is a darling boy- Have you succeeded in
obtaining a nurse for Lawrence yet? I do trust you
have & that you have got an excellent one- Are
you enjoying yourself all you can, my darling
Emilie? Now don't forget, my loved wife, that I
insist upon it that you must cast aside every
care you can & be such a bright & gay little
darling- and do you do just what you please & I
will be responsible for it- If you need more
money, don't hesitate to write & I will, with the
greatest pleasure in life, send it to my darling
little wifie, who is the best & dearest little
woman in this whole world- Don't forget it-
we have just heard that Army appropriation
bill has passed, so that our pay is secure
for another year- Genl Oakes has left Arizona,
which puts Col. Compton in Command of the Reg-
-iment & I think the band with Mr Carter &
Kerr, will soon be at Apache- Won't that be
grand? If so, won't these old hills about Apache
echo to the sweet music every day & night?
How, I wish my loved ones could be here to
enjoy it! but I'd rather they were where they are,
for their sakes-
Saturday night, 17th- Did I tell my darling little wife,
that Camp Apache has had its name changed and
is now called Fort Apache? Remember this, Emilie dar-
ling, & direct those many sweet letters you are going
to write accordingly- I succeeded in getting the two
panes of glass, from the Quartermaster, to supply the
place of the broken ones, and Altman, this morning, put
them in very nicely, so that the cold, night draughts
are effectually excluded. I got the pink ribbon from
the Sutter's to-day, & now my curtains are looped back
most winsomely- but not as prettily as my precious wifie
would have done it- Love your dear heart, Emilie,
how Mantee missed you when he came to arrange
his room. How much I needed my smart little
darling to tell me just where this thing & that should
go! I know of no one who can put a room in
as perfect order and fitness as my Emilie
wife, who isn't petted half enough- Bless her
heart & papa's boy's little life, how much he misses
them every day. Oh! when I go away from this old
house on any errand & then come back & enter
it, and find no wifie & no “bad daddies”, my heart
comes right into my mouth! It seems so strange
when I go out to the water barrell & look into the
back window on my return & not see my darling
boy standing in his crib, waiting to laugh &
hollow at papa- To tell the truth, darling, I can't
bear the sight of that horrid, old window- And
to-day, I found “didn't day's” nursing bottle with
the old torn nipple on it! These reminders of my
precious darlings meet me at every turn and make
me so sad for the time; but I guess I must become
used to it. Altman & I have got the strings up
for the hop vines on the parlor side of the house &
around the porch- Monday we will complete the other
side- The vines are already taking hold of the strings that
we have put up & as Altman gives them plenty
of water every evening they will soon look beauti-
ful- The Nuncio frequently speaks of Lawrence &
often remarks that there are not many such
fine children- Says that he has observed closely
but that he has never seen a finer, stronger boy,
He often inquires of you too & says he lost a
“good friends by mr's Reed going away”! I think he
will be a good striker for me, as he seem to be
very attentive- So far he keeps my room in nice order.
Well, my sweet little wifie, as it is about 10 A.M. & little
Undie lies stretched before the fire & is snoring her very
best, I think I had better say “goodnight” to my own precious
darling, and “pleasant dreams”- Oh! to press you to my heart for
one moment! Goodnight & sweet kisses to papa's boy also-
Sunday, May 18- I had been waiting very impatiently
all day for the mail to arrive, thinking that I would
certainly get a long letter from darling little wifie, but
instead I only got a postal forwarded from Wingate
by Dr Torney- This was written the same day on which
you reached Norfolk- Bless your darling heart,
my lovely wife, I know your heart was full of joy
when you at last found a resting place & so many
dear friends- Nothing pleases me more than to know
that you are happy & where you can rest & enjoy
your sweet self; and that you have succeeded in
procuring a good woman for as a nurse for our
darling boy. Oh! Emilie, love, what a relief it
must be to you, to be able to sit down among
your family & friends and be undisturbed by the
dread & fear of soldier cooks leaving you- Husband
knows what a perfect respite it must be to you
darling, & he rejoices accordingly. No man loves &
appreciates his wife more than your own dear
Mantee, and he knows too that no wife ever loved her husband more
devotedly than his own, precious, sweet, darling “ooman-
tee”! Isn't that so, Emilie, wifie! Oh! to know that you
are back East once more, away from Arizona
cares and burdens & with your own dear loved ones;
when I think of this, I could easily shed tears of
happiness & thankfulness- I miss you, darling; yes
miss you & Lawrence sorely; but yet I had so much
rather that you should be where you are, under
no circumstances could I ever consent to your return
to Arizona- Next October, I hope to start East to join my
sweet wife & boy- May is more than half gone & the
time will soon fly past, but not too swiftly for me
whose most ardent desire is to see my own pre-
cious wife & darling son again-

By the way, did you know that Miss Carrie Wilkins
was married? I was perfectly astonished to hear
of it- She was married in Washington, about
the middle of April to her old admirer, Captain
Porter, 8th Infantry. Mrs. Andrews writes to Mrs.
Harrison that she was present and that Miss
Carrie looked very pretty. By this time, Mrs.
Andrews is almost ready to start back to her
Post. Mrs. Harrison says that she was com-
-pletely lost for a few days after you and
Lawrence left- Never missed any one so
much in her life. She sends all manner of
love & kind messages. Mrs. Hentig is looking bet-
ter than I ever saw her. Sends much love, Is
very much obliged to you for your trouble
in getting the hat- Mrs. Harrison now vows that
she will come East when I am ordered out-
She is not looking very well & says she is so
tired & worn out with Apache that she thinks
she will die, if she has to remain here all of
1879- I was premature in my allusion to the
appropriation bill. It has not yet passed, but
is pretty sure to do so-

Tuesday 20th may. You perceive my darling little
wifie, that I have been writing this letter by piece
-meal. A little every day, except Monday Tuesday- Did
I tell my little apple-pie, that I arrived at Apache
with a very sore throat? I am now quite
well, but, I assure you, darling, that I had a
pretty sick time of it for a few days. Caught
the cold the night we stopped at McCarty's
Ranch-slept out of doors & had nothing to put
on my head- I tell you, Emilie, love, I missed
my cap very much- well, three days after,
when I reached Luni, my throat not only was
very sore, but I was so hoarse that I couldn't
speak above a whisper. & that night very
sick at my stomach- You remember the
wind & sand at Zuni, the day we arrived there,
well two days could not be more alike than
the day in April & the one in May- The sand was
perfectly blinding & Dr Eli's room in greater
confusion than ever- They are living in all the
uproar, & dirt as when we saw them- I had
told Mrs. Compton about the room, & how you
sat & gazed out of the window so abstractedly-
She said that she was not surprised at what
I told her of your feelings; that as for herself
she was completely dazed. Oh! the sand & the dirt:
next morning when we left, the wind an was
blowing so cold, that Mrs. C. & I sat inside with
all windows down & five blankets & the robe
over us- In fact we did not have a warm
day on our return- Before I forget it, darling,
please send my cap (I mean the one “bad daddies” wore)
& a cravat by the first mail, after you get this.
The mails are now alright & run regularly- I
am going to study Spanish very hard till I come-
know how to ask for “agua chicita” & many
other things- I must close, my letter, though I do so
very reluctantly- Heaven bless & guard you
my own precious Emilie & sweet little son- send
papa his photograph as soon as you can have
it taken, for he is so anxious to see his boy- Your's too dar-
ling, if you will have it taken-

closer.salute:
Best love to all- a thousand
kisses from papa to mother & son- write very often to your devoted
husband who thinks of his sweet wife always.
